history: The Boxer descends from two types of German Bullenbeisers, or bull-biters.
The Bullenbeisers were originally used to chase large game, such as boar, deer, and bear, through the forests, grabbing and hanging on until the hunter could arrive to dispatch it.
In the early 1800s, German hunters tried to improve their hunting dogs by crossing their Bullenbeisers with mastiff-type dogs and with Bulldogs.
By the late 1800s, these dogs were popular as butcher's dogs, controlling cattle in slaughter yards.
The slaughter yard dogs were called Boxl, which may have been the origin of the name, Boxer.
The Boxer was established by 1895.
The Boxer was one of the first breeds used as a police and military dog.
In 1904, the AKC recognized the Boxer.
The breed remained relatively obscure in America until the 1940s, when it began its slow but steady rise.
behavior: Makes a loyal and protective companion.
Playful and gentle with children.
Fairly outgoing toward strangers.
Generally good with other dogs, but some can be aggressive toward strange dogs.
Generally good with other pets.
Learns quickly, but can be both sensitive and stubborn.
Does best with a firm owner who can combine reward-based training with good control and leadership.
exercise_needs: Makes a calm and alert housedog, but can be restless unless it receives adequate exercise.
Requires daily exercise in the form of a long walk, jog or energetic games.
The Boxer's short muzzle makes it intolerant of heat.
The Boxer's short coat makes it intolerant of very cold weather.
Obedience training is essential not only for control, but for the mental exercise it provides.
Boxers compete in obedience and agility successfully.
grooming: Coat is short and shiny.
It needs only occasional brushing, once every week or so, to remove dead hair.
Shedding is average.
nutrition: Boxers tend to stay in good weight.
Adult dogs should be fed a balanced diet, with restricted calories if the dog starts to gain too much weight.
Puppies should be fed a large-breed growth food, which slows their growing rate but not final size. This may decrease the incidence or severity of hip dysplasia in adults.

history: Developed in Scotland in the mid-19th century as a retriever for hunting and shooting parties.
Lord Tweedmouth is credited with developing the breed by crossing a Yellow Retriever with the now-extinct Tweed Water Spaniel.
Irish Setter, Bloodhound, and more Tweed Water Spaniel were added later.
First exhibited in 1908 at the UK's Crystal Palace show as 'Flat Coats - Golden'.
Officially recognized by The Kennel Club in 1913.
Gained popularity in the US in the 1970s and has been one of America's most popular dog breeds for decades.
behavior: Famously friendly, reliable, and trustworthy.
Excellent family dogs with a patient, kindly demeanor.
Highly social and gets along well with other dogs and pets.
Eager to please and highly trainable.
Intelligent and devoted companions.
Retains puppy-like playfulness well into adulthood.
Generally not effective as guard dogs due to their friendly nature.
exercise_needs: Requires at least one hour of moderate exercise daily.
Enjoys swimming, retrieving games, and outdoor activities.
Mental stimulation through training and play is important.
Can be prone to weight gain without adequate exercise.
Excels in dog sports like obedience, agility, tracking, and field trials.
grooming: Dense, water-repellent double coat with moderate shedding year-round and heavy seasonal shedding.
Requires brushing at least once or twice weekly, more during shedding seasons.
Ears should be checked regularly to prevent infections.
Occasional baths help keep coat clean and reduce shedding.
nutrition: Diet should be appropriate to the dog's age, size, and activity level.
Prone to obesity, so careful monitoring of food intake and weight is important.
High-quality dog food, whether commercially manufactured or home-prepared, is essential.
Clean, fresh water should be available at all times.

history: Developed in Germany in the late 19th century by Captain Max von Stephanitz.
Originally bred for herding sheep and protecting flocks.
First breed entry was registered in 1899.
Gained recognition for their service in World War I as messenger dogs, rescuers, and supply carriers.
Introduced to the United States in the early 1900s.
Widely used in police work, military service, search and rescue, and as service dogs.
behavior: Intelligent, confident, and courageous.
Loyal and protective of their family.
Can be aloof with strangers but not usually aggressive without cause.
Strong work ethic and desire to have a purpose.
Forms strong bonds with family members.
Highly trainable with consistent leadership.
Requires early socialization to develop well-balanced temperament.
exercise_needs: High energy breed requiring significant daily exercise.
Needs at least 1-2 hours of physical activity daily.
Mental stimulation through training and problem-solving is essential.
Excels in dog sports like obedience, tracking, herding, and agility.
Without adequate exercise and mental stimulation, may develop behavioral problems.
grooming: Double coat with a dense outer coat and thick undercoat.
Sheds year-round with heavy seasonal shedding (blowing coat).
Requires brushing 3-4 times a week, daily during shedding seasons.
Bathing only when necessary to preserve natural oils in coat.
Regular nail trimming, ear cleaning, and dental care needed.
nutrition: Diet should be high-quality and appropriate for age, size, and activity level.
Prone to bloat, so multiple smaller meals are recommended over one large meal.
Careful monitoring of weight is important to prevent obesity.
Puppies should be fed a large-breed puppy formula to support proper growth and development.
